results.title: Smoke
results.creator_credit: Wayne Wang, Greg Johnson, Peter Newman, Euro Space and Neue Deutsche Filmgesellschaft
results.brief_description: Wayne Wang’s “Smoke” is a beautifully crafted film that weaves together the stories of a group of characters whose lives intersect at Augie Wren’s (Harvery Keitel) cigar shop. Paul Benjamin (William Hurt) is a writer who is trying to recover from the death of his wife. He runs into ‘Rasheed’ who is looking for his father. Meanwhile Ruby McNutt (Stockard Channing) is trying to convince Augie that her heroin addicted daughter is his. Keitel acts as an anchoring force in “Smoke” as the characters’ stories unfold lesuirely and lovingly. (Awards: Winner of the 1995 Berlin Film Festival International Critics Prize and Special Jury Prize)

results.title: Smiley's people
results.creator_credit: Simon Langton, Jonathon Powell and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: John Le Carre’s character Smiley is bought to life by Sir Alec Guinness in this acclaimed dramatisation. Compulsive viewing to the end, Smiley is called out of retirement to the aid of the Circus. He returns with a vengeance. The assassination of an emigre Soviet and British agent, General Vladimir, sends Smiley delving into the past on a twisted trail across Europe that moves inexorably towards a final showdown with his old adversary and arch-enemy, Karla - leader of Moscow centre.

results.title: Smokers' lungs
results.creator_credit: Joe Licastro, Don Hopkins and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: No one would inflict external injury to himself—because the consequence is immediately seen and felt. The lungs, however, being out of sight, can be subjected to years of abuse before a smoker takes warning. In this film, Dr. D.W. Thompson of the Toronto General Hospital demonstrates, through a series of color slides of lungs and lung tissue, how the persistent, prolonged irritation of cigarette smoke can bring about drastic, even fatal, changes in the lungs—convincing evidence that smoking can and does cause cancer and other lung disease. A film for the lay audience as well as for use by medical personnel.

results.title: Small smoke at Blaze Creek
results.creator_credit: Michael Scott, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Forest fire in mountainous British Columbia, as experienced by the men who must try to quench it from the air and at close quarters on the ground. Over half of fire outbreaks occur through carelessness, and this film affords a close, vivid view of the result: a whole mountainside turned into a searing, crackling holocaust until nothing remains but grey, desolate waste—mute reproach to all who travel or work in the forests. (Awards: Berlin; Belgrade.)

results.title: Small island, big fight
results.creator_credit: Aven S Noah, Rosemary Hesp, Trevor Graham, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Australia and Junjidys Productions
results.brief_description: …Where I come from is Murray Island. We call it Mer. The home of the famous Mabo land rights case. We won that battle, but now we’ve got a new fight on our hands…this time with outside fishing fleets over who can profit from our waters. (Aven S. Noah) Situated on the eastern side of the Torres Strait between Papua New Guinea and Australia, Murray Island or Mer, is home to around 450 indigenous people with each family belonging to one of eight clans. Following the historic Mabo case which won recognition for traditional ownership of their land, the Mer people are now fighting for the same recognition of their sea - land and sea are all part of Aboriginal territory and have a historical cultural link to their spiritual beliefs and customs. Their sea is being invaded by commercial fishing fleets and local islanders are struggling to compete - already some have left the Island and three-quarters of the population are on welfare. What has not been resolved by the Mabo case must now be resolved by the Torres Strait Treaty which was designed to protect indigenous rights to fishing and environmental concerns. The documentary presents all sides to the argument including interviews with the commercial fishermen, Mer Island fishermen and community leaders, and legal representatives for the Mer people as well as archival footage of Eddie “Koiki” Mabo discussing sea rights in 1989. Narrated by Aven S. Noah.

results.title: Sleeping Beauty
results.brief_description: This production of the classic ballet, “Sleeping Beauty” is performed by the Australian Ballet. Performed live at The Victorian Arts Centre, October 9, 1984, this ballet in a prologue and three acts has the beautiful Christine Walsh dancing the role of Aurora with touches of tenderness and grace, and David Ashmole creating an outstanding Prince Florimund. Music is performed by The Elizabethan Melbourne Orchestra, conducted by Ritchie Hanna.
